resource.description: Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come

footnotes.footnote: This re-imagined Donald Duck cartoon remix was constructed using 50 classic Walt Disney cartoons from the 1930s through 1960s combined with audio clips from Glenn Beck broadcasts.

The title card re-design and photoshop work was volunteered by graphic designer Justin McIntosh. He worked to match the style to the original Disney cartoon credits and titles from the 1940s cartoons.
In the 1930's Walt Disney introduced Donald Duck to represent the average working "everyman" who could express frustrations in ways Mickey Mouse no longer could because of his role model icon status.
In the original cartoon Donald is fighting with a bee. The bee has been removed frame-by-frame to make it seem more like Donald is reacting to what he sees inside the window. - [See original scene]
The top 1% of Americans now own more wealth than the bottom 90% combined. In 2009 the number of millionaires rose 16% while 4 million additional Americans fell into poverty.

In 2009 the wealth gap between rich and poor grew to levels not seen in America since 1929. The number of Americans living in extreme poverty jumped by 11% with over 44 million living below the poverty line.

Government tax rates for the rich over the past 30 years, under both political parties, have contributed to the widening wealth gap. The top 1% of Americans now have tax rates a third lower than they had back in 1970.

The initial bank bailout passed under George W. Bush with support from then senator Barack Obama and the Democrats. In early 2009 president-elect Obama lobbied congress intensely to extend it and release $350 billion more.
The headline refers to the "real unemployment" rate and not the official government numbers of 9.5%. In September 2010 real unemployment was estimated to be between 16.5% and 22%.

The most difficult cartoon to acquire was the TV special "Duck for Hire" co-starring Ranger Woodlore which only aired on Disney's Wonderful World of Color. This clip is from a TV broadcast recording onto VHS.
In the original cartoon the writing says "rent". Here it was necessary to modify it to read "mortgage" instead to fit the new narrative. - [See original scene]

One of the reasons for using classic Disney cartoons for this remix is the fact that the Walt Disney conglomerate has pushed for long extensions to copyright limitations to protect Mickey Mouse from entering the public domain.

In the original cartoon Pete is serving a notice of "dispossession" to both Donald and Mickey Mouse. It was necessary to modify the notice frame-by-frame to read "foreclosure" for the new narrative. [See original scene]
In 2009 home foreclosures hit a record high of 3 million in the United States. 2010 saw 2.9 million foreclosures while the Wall St. firms responsible for the crisis walked away with bail outs.

The Glenn Beck Program is the 3rd highest rated radio talk program in the United States with an estimated 10 million weekly listeners. Conservative hosts Rush Limbaugh and Sean Hannity are ranked 1st and 2nd.

In a 2009 interview with CEO Patrick Byrne Glenn Beck uncharacteristically agrees that the government is "owned" by Wall St. which is odd given his usual rants about government constraints on big business.

The 1943 propaganda cartoon "The New Spirit" provided the core framework for this project. It was a partnership between Disney and the US Department of the Treasury to persuade Americans to pay their taxes during World War II.

Walt Disney himself joined Joseph McCarthy's Hollywood witch hunts and testified as a friendly witness before the House Un-American Activities Committee in 1947 claiming communists had tried to take over his studio.

The Nazi marching band is appropriated from a 1943 American war propaganda cartoon called "Der Fuehrer's Face" in which Donald Duck has a nightmare about being a Nazi soldier in Germany during World War II.

One inspiration for this project was an interview with linguist Noam Chomsky where he says it's a mistake to ridicule people drawn to the Tea Party. This is why Donald Duck is presented as a sympathetic character in the remix.

Beck's rhetoric relies on race-coded language and racist scapegoating techniques designed to stoke racial fears and resentments in white Americans while appealing to a white nostalgia for some mythical bygone era.

The Three Caballeros came out of a US Government "Good Neighbor Policy" propaganda effort in Latin America after World War II. Though created by Disney as a friend of Donald, Panchito is still a racist stereotyped mexican character.
Yes Glenn Beck actually did bark like a mad dog live television. It happened on February 17th 2010 during his Fox News Channel broadcast while he was discussing Obama's stimulus package.

The "pygmy cannibals" are from the 1954 cartoon "Spare the Rod". In the 1960s Disney cut the racist scenes before airing it on TV. Unfortunately the stereotypes mirror current images used in Tea Party protests against Obama.

Glenn Beck's Insider Extreme is a paid subscription service that offers live and archived video feeds of his four radio broadcast each day for $9.95 per month. It also offers access to his "historical" documentaries.

In the original cartoon Donald runs past the mailbox without depositing the letter. It was necessary to digitally add the letter being placed into the mailbox and to have it spin around. [See original scene]
When Glenn Beck says "stupid Disney cartoon" he is mocking MSNBC Morning Joe co-host Mika Brzezinski's name on his Sept 17, 2009 radio broadcast.
In the original cartoon Donald pulls an egg out of his pocket. Here it has been replaced with his foreclosure notice. [See original scene]
In the original cartoon Donald is showing his last will and testament. Here it has been photophopped to turn it into his foreclosure notice. [See original scene]

As in this May 2010 clip Glenn Beck occasionally uses his national broadcasts to mock homeowners facing foreclosure proceedings from big banks. He also refers to victims of predatory lending practices as "the real predators".

In the original cartoon Donald is pointing his shotgun at a small penguin. Here the Tootsberry Institute of Temperism Insult Machine from "Cured Duck" has been cut out frame-by-frame and composited in. [See original scene]

This is a frame-by-frame composite created by lifting Donald from "Chef Donald" and adding the hole in the wall from "Donald's Penguin". Color correction was also done to make the colors match. [See original scene]

This transformative remix work constitutes a fair use of any copyrighted material as provided for in section 107 of the US copyright law. The work is licensed as Creative Commons permitting non-commercial sharing with attribution.
